intro: Plagiobothrys dispar, commonly known as the narrowleaf sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in coastal areas and inland deserts. Its leaves are narrow and linear, and it produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. Plagiobothrys dispar is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils through its extensive root system.
